  physical_appearance: This painting shows a ship at anchor. On the stern of the ship
 there is an image of a large bird with the sun. There is another ship on the background on the left. On the right of the painting there is a structure on land. On the foreground of the image there are two boats with men rowing.

  sgcool_label_text: This painting shows a Chinese junk at anchor
 probably outside a trading port in China
 perhaps Canton. The ships were used for trade with Southeast Asia and other areas
 transporting rattan
 bamboo
 tea
 tin
 lead
 sago
 salt
 porcelain
 and other goods. The large bird near the sun on the stern is likely the mythical phoenix (feng huang). At right is a structure on land
 possibly a fort. \r\n\r\nProduced largely for visiting tourists and foreign traders
 these works were known as China trade paintings
 and were popular in the 18th and 19th centuries. They were produced by local and foreign artists
 working in a Western style
 to appeal to the market.

metadata.physical_appearance: This painting shows a ship at anchor. On the stern of the ship, there is an image of a large bird with the sun. There is another ship on the background on the left. On the right of the painting there is a structure on land. On the foreground of the image there are two boats with men rowing.
metadata.subject_terms_1: Chinese (culture or style) junks (vessels) harbors trade (function) seaports
metadata.subject_terms_2: Painting China trade painting Harbors Junks
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This painting shows a Chinese junk at anchor, probably outside a trading port in China, perhaps Canton. The ships were used for trade with Southeast Asia and other areas, transporting rattan, bamboo, tea, tin, lead, sago, salt, porcelain, and other goods. The large bird near the sun on the stern is likely the mythical phoenix (feng huang). At right is a structure on land, possibly a fort. 

Produced largely for visiting tourists and foreign traders, these works were known as China trade paintings, and were popular in the 18th and 19th centuries. They were produced by local and foreign artists, working in a Western style, to appeal to the market.
